mn143:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn143:2.1: Now at that time the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
mn143:2.3: “Please, mister, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
mn143:2.4: ‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
mn143:2.5: He bows with his head to your feet.’
mn143:2.6: Then go to Venerable Sāriputta, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
mn143:2.7: ‘Sir, the householder Anāthapiṇḍika is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
mn143:2.8: He bows with his head to your feet.’
mn143:2.10: ‘Sir, please visit him at his home out of compassion.’”
mn143:2.11: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Anāthapiṇḍika asked.
mn143:3.1: Then Venerable Sāriputta robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went with Venerable Ānanda as his second monk to Anāthapiṇḍika’s home. He sat down on the seat spread out, and said to Anāthapiṇḍika,
mn143:3.2: “Householder, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
mn143:4.1: “I’m not keeping well, Master Sāriputta, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing, not its fading, is evident.
mn143:4.2: The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.
mn143:4.4: The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
mn143:4.6: The winds piercing my belly are so severe, it feels like a deft butcher or their apprentice is slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
mn143:4.8: The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals. That’s how severe the burning is in my body.
mn143:4.9: I’m not keeping well, Master Sāriputta, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading, its growing, not its fading, is evident.”
mn143:5.1: “That’s why, householder, you should train like this:
mn143:5.2: ‘I shall not grasp the eye, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the eye.’
mn143:5.5: ‘I shall not grasp the ear, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the ear.’ …
mn143:5.8: ‘I shall not grasp the nose, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the nose.’ …
mn143:5.11: ‘I shall not grasp the tongue, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the tongue.’ …
mn143:5.14: ‘I shall not grasp the body, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the body.’ …
mn143:5.17: ‘I shall not grasp the mind, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the mind.’
mn143:6.2: ‘I shall not grasp sight, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on sight.’ …
mn143:6.9: thought, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on thought.’
mn143:7.2: ‘I shall not grasp eye consciousness, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on eye consciousness.’ …
mn143:7.9: mind consciousness, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on mind consciousness.’
mn143:8.9: mind contact, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on mind contact.’
mn143:9.2: ‘I shall not grasp feeling born of eye contact …
mn143:9.9: feeling born of mind contact, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the feeling born of mind contact.’
mn143:10.2: ‘I shall not grasp the earth element …
mn143:10.9: consciousness element, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the consciousness element.’
mn143:11.8: consciousness, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on consciousness.’
mn143:12.2: ‘I shall not grasp the dimension of infinite space …
mn143:12.7: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
mn143:13.2: ‘I shall not grasp this world, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on this world.’
mn143:14.2: ‘I shall not grasp the other world, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on the other world.’
mn143:14.5: ‘I shall not grasp whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, sought, and explored by my mind, and there shall be no consciousness of mine dependent on that.’
mn143:15.1: When he said this, Anāthapiṇḍika cried and burst out in tears.
mn143:15.3: “Are you failing, householder? Are you fading, householder?”
mn143:15.5: But for a long time I have paid homage to the Buddha and the esteemed mendicants.
mn143:15.6: Yet I have never before heard such a Dhamma talk.”
mn143:15.7: “Householder, it does not occur to us to teach such a Dhamma talk to white-clothed laypeople.
mn143:15.8: Rather, we teach like this to those gone forth.”
mn143:15.9: “Well then, Master Sāriputta, let it occur to you to teach such a Dhamma talk to white-clothed laypeople as well!
mn143:15.10: There are gentlemen with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.
mn143:15.11: There will be those who understand the teaching!”
mn143:16.1: And when the venerables Sāriputta and Ānanda had given the householder Anāthapiṇḍika this advice they got up from their seat and left.
mn143:16.2: Not long after they had left, Anāthapiṇḍika passed away and was reborn in the host of Joyful Gods.
mn143:17.1: Then, late at night, the glorious god Anāthapiṇḍika, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
mn143:17.2: and addressed the Buddha in verse:
mn143:17.4: frequented by the Saṅgha of hermits,
mn143:17.5: where the King of Dhamma stayed:
mn143:17.14: and thus be purified in it.
mn143:17.17: Any mendicant who has crossed over
mn143:18.1: This is what the god Anāthapiṇḍika said,
mn143:18.4: knowing that the teacher approved, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.
mn143:19.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha told the mendicants all that had happened.
mn143:20.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
mn143:20.2: “Sir, that god must surely have been Anāthapiṇḍika.
mn143:20.3: For the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was devoted to Venerable Sāriputta.”
mn143:20.5: You’ve reached the logical conclusion, as far as logic goes.
mn143:20.6: For that was indeed the god Anāthapiṇḍika.”
mn143:20.7: That is what the Buddha said.
mn143:20.8: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
